mn61:3.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
mn61:3.3: Now at that time Venerable Rāhula was staying at Ambalaṭṭhika.
mn61:3.4: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of solitude and went to Ambalaṭṭhika to see Venerable Rāhula.
mn61:3.5: Rāhula saw the Buddha coming off in the distance.
mn61:3.6: He prepared a seat and water for washing the feet.
mn61:3.7: The Buddha sat on the prepared seat.
mn61:3.9: Rāhula bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side.
mn61:4.1: Then the Buddha, leaving a little water in the pot, addressed Rāhula:
mn61:4.2: “Rāhula, do you see this little bit of water left in the pot?”
mn61:4.4: “That’s how the little of the ascetic’s nature is left in those who are not ashamed to tell a deliberate lie.”
mn61:4.5: Then the Buddha, tossing away what little water was left in the pot, addressed Rāhula:
mn61:4.6: “Do you see this little bit of water that was tossed away?”
mn61:4.8: “That’s how the ascetic’s nature is tossed away in those who are not ashamed to tell a deliberate lie.”
mn61:4.9: Then the Buddha, turning the pot upside down, addressed Rāhula:
mn61:4.10: “Do you see how this pot is turned upside down?”
mn61:4.12: “That’s how the ascetic’s nature is turned upside down in those who are not ashamed to tell a deliberate lie.”
mn61:4.13: Then the Buddha, turning the pot right side up, addressed Rāhula:
mn61:4.14: “Do you see how this pot is vacant and empty?”
mn61:4.16: “That’s how vacant and empty the ascetic’s nature is in those who are not ashamed to tell a deliberate lie.
mn61:4.17: Suppose there was a royal bull elephant with tusks like plows, able to draw a heavy load, pedigree and battle-hardened. In battle it uses its fore-feet and hind-feet, its fore-quarters and hind-quarters, its head, ears, tusks, and tail,
mn61:4.18: but it still protects its trunk.
mn61:4.24: It has not fully dedicated its life.’
mn61:4.25: But when that royal bull elephant … in battle uses its fore-feet and hind-feet, its fore-quarters and hind-quarters, its head, ears, tusks, and tail,
mn61:4.27: and its trunk, its rider thinks:
mn61:4.28: ‘This royal bull elephant … in battle uses its fore-feet and hind-feet, its fore-quarters and hind-quarters, its head, ears, tusks, and tail, and its trunk.
mn61:4.29: It has fully dedicated its life.
mn61:4.30: Now there is nothing that royal bull elephant would not do.’
mn61:4.31: In the same way, when someone is not ashamed to tell a deliberate lie, there is no bad deed they would not do, I say.
mn61:4.32: So you should train like this: ‘I will not tell a lie, even for a joke.’
mn61:5.1: What do you think, Rāhula? What is the purpose of a mirror?”
mn61:7.1: “In the same way, deeds of body, speech, and mind should be done only after repeated reflection.
mn61:7.2: When you want to act with the body, you should reflect on that same deed:
mn61:7.3: ‘Does this act with the body that I want to do lead to hurting myself, hurting others, and hurting both?
mn61:7.4: Is it unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result?’
mn61:7.5: If, while reflecting in this way, you know:
mn61:7.6: ‘This act with the body that I want to do leads to hurting myself, hurting others, and hurting both.
mn61:7.7: It’s unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result.’ To the best of your ability, Rāhula, you should not do such a deed.
mn61:7.8: But if, while reflecting in this way, you know:
mn61:7.9: ‘This act with the body that I want to do doesn’t lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both.
mn61:7.10: It’s skillful, with happiness as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should do such a deed.
mn61:8.1: While you are acting with the body, you should reflect on that same act:
mn61:8.2: ‘Does this act with the body that I am doing lead to hurting myself, hurting others, and hurting both?
mn61:8.3: Is it unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result?’
mn61:8.4: If, while reflecting in this way, you know:
mn61:8.5: ‘This act with the body that I am doing leads to hurting myself, hurting others, and hurting both.
mn61:8.6: It’s unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should desist from such a deed.
mn61:8.7: But if, while reflecting in this way, you know:
mn61:8.8: ‘This act with the body that I am doing doesn’t lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both.
mn61:8.9: It’s skillful, with happiness as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should continue doing such a deed.
mn61:9.1: After you have acted with the body, you should reflect on that same act:
mn61:9.2: ‘Does this act with the body that I have done lead to hurting myself, hurting others, and hurting both?
mn61:9.3: Is it unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result?’
mn61:9.4: If, while reflecting in this way, you know:
mn61:9.5: ‘This act with the body that I have done leads to hurting myself, hurting others, and hurting both.
mn61:9.6: It’s unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should confess, reveal, and clarify such a deed to the Teacher or a sensible spiritual companion.
mn61:9.7: And having revealed it you should restrain yourself in future.
mn61:9.8: But if, while reflecting in this way, you know:
mn61:9.9: ‘This act with the body that I have done doesn’t lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both.
mn61:9.10: It’s skillful, with happiness as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should live in rapture and joy because of this, continuing to train day and night in wholesome qualities.
mn61:10.1: When you want to act with speech …
mn61:13.1: When you want to act with the mind …
mn61:15.8: But if, while reflecting in this way, you know:
mn61:15.9: ‘This act with the mind that I have done doesn’t lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both.
mn61:15.10: It’s skillful, with happiness as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should live in rapture and joy because of this, continuing to train day and night in wholesome qualities.
mn61:16.1: All the ascetics and brahmins of the past, future, and present who purify their physical, verbal, and mental actions do so after repeated reflection.
mn61:16.4: So Rāhula, you should train yourself like this: ‘I will purify my physical, verbal, and mental actions after repeated reflection.’”
mn61:17.1: This is what the Buddha said.
mn61:17.2: Uplifted, Venerable Rāhula approved of what the Buddha said.
